awd_titl_txt: SaTC: Student Travel Support for 2020 Conference on Decision and Game Theory for Security (GameSec)
awd_abstract_narration:
This proposal supports student travel for 10 students to attend the 2020 Conference on Decision and Game Theory for Security (GameSec) to be held in University of Maryland, College Park, October 28-30, 2020. The GameSec is a leading venue for quick and wide dissemination of cutting-edge research results in on the analytical models based on game, information, communication, optimization, decision, and control theories that are applied to diverse security topics. This travel grant will enable career development and learning opportunities for US-based and/or US citizen graduate students. Attending conferences is an important component of graduate school education for our society's future computer security researchers. Students will have the opportunity to discuss leading edge research with world-class computer security researchers, and establish networks, connections, and mentoring relationships that will serve them well during their research careers.

This grant provides travel support to encourage participation in the 2020 GameSec by students who would normally find it difficult to attend. Criteria for selection include evidence of a serious interest in the field, as demonstrated by research output, coursework and/or project experience. Organizers encourage participation of women and students from other under-represented groups.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The GameSec conference serves as a premier platform that brings together researchers dedicated to establishing a solid theoretical foundation for making resource allocation decisions while effectively balancing available capabilities and perceived security risks. By focusing on analytical models derived from game theory, information theory, communication theory, optimization, decision theory, and control theory, the conference covers a wide range of security topics. Moreover, the conference places a strong emphasis on bridging the gap between theoretical models and real-world security challenges, ensuring a vital feedback loop between theory and practice.

 

For students, the conference presents a unique opportunity to attend an in-person event for the first time. Notably, the conference features renowned researchers in the field who deliver plenary talks, adding further value to the student experience. This grant has enabled students to showcase their own work, refine their communication skills, engage with senior researchers, and explore new research directions. Distinct from many large conferences, GameSec distinguishes itself as a focused, topic-specific gathering, allowing attendees ample time to interact, exchange ideas, and envision innovative directions.

 

GameSec stands out as a vital venue for the science of security, bringing together researchers from diverse disciplines such as social sciences, economics, computer science, operations research, and engineering. Its growth serves as a testament to an emerging field dedicated to a profound understanding of cyber defense and strategies. Additionally, the conference offers unique educational experiences that go beyond traditional classroom settings. Supporting student participation in this conference represents an investment in the future workforce and leaders in cybersecurity who possess the knowledge and skills to address not only technical aspects but also the social and economic dimensions of security.

 

Through this project, seven students have received support to participate in the GameSec 2022 conference. This support has significantly enhanced the representation and involvement of graduate students, who represent the future cybersecurity workforce. The grant has provided assistance to both MS and PhD students, as well as aspiring undergraduate students seeking to become security engineers. The conference offers them a platform to acquire knowledge about the latest scientific methods developed for security and privacy. The travel support has effectively increased student participation, fostering the development of the next generation of security researchers. Furthermore, the conference's focus on establishing a theoretical foundation for understanding security risks in a principled manner contributes to promoting the science of security as a field of study.
